key_points: Former Secretary of State Colin Powell died from COVID-19 complications amid a cancer battle at age 84.
Powell was fully vaccinated but had been treated for multiple myeloma, a blood cancer affecting the immune system.
President Biden ordered flags at half-staff until October 22 in remembrance of Powell and commended his dignity and patriotism.
Powell was the first Black secretary of state and served under four presidents, including as National Security Advisor and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
He led the State Department during the 9/11 attacks and supported the invasion of Iraq, later calling his UN speech on WMDs a "blot" on his record.
Despite serving Republican administrations, Powell endorsed Democrats in later years, including Obama, Clinton, and Biden.
Former President George W. Bush praised Powell as a "great public servant" and expressed condolences to his family.
Colin Powell was recognized for challenging conspiracy theories about Obama's faith during the 2008 election.
Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin paid tribute to Powell's legacy and leadership.
International condolences came from France, highlighting Powell's status as a respected military leader and statesman.
spokespersons: François Delattre (Secretary General, French Ministry of Europe and Foreign Affairs)
